------=_NextPart_000_00D7_01C44A6A.D6E69140
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

John, Colin, Ken and Derek,

I am wondering if there is not a wee bit too m=
uch focus on topological vairation and insignificant focus on just weight m=
utation.  I get that NEAT is unique in the fact that it has a very effectiv=
e search mechanism for topoligical variation, with the ability to stress bo=
th additive and subtractive aspects of change.  And I get that it is fun to=
 focus on the topological variation as it is somewhat spatially interesting=
.

However, I am realizing that just doing effective weight mutations, sans=
 topological changes, can end up producing solutions that are very "fit".  =
I have been focused on reproducing the experiments Fogel and Kumar produced=
 which are covered in their book Blondie24.  In that, they had only 3 topol=
ogies they experimented with.  All of the GA searching was just done with w=
eight mutation within a step size that was both a GA parameter and nudged t=
owards smaller values.  In the Fogel experiments, they arrived at an expert=
 player (well, at least against human opponents) using just co-evolution an=
d a static topology.  And in my own replication of the experiments, somethi=
ng as simple as turn on/off biases had a substantial effect in how long it =
took to arrive at a specimen of similar fitness.

Now, I realize that mutat=
ing weights only is not near as sexy sounding as both weight mutation and t=
opological variation.  However, what I am wondering and hope to be able to =
evaluate with experimentation is whether the topological mutation rates oug=
ht not be very small with the focus more on trying out many weight mutation=
s within a given topology?  What is occurring to me is that just doing weig=
ht mutation is a search at a rate X in a huge space.  And it seems to me ad=
ding topological variation is not just a multiplier, but an exponent increa=
sing X.  Perhaps the space is being made too large too quickly, before a se=
arch just in the weight mutation space might demonstrate a uniquely fit ind=
ividual.

My understanding is that the "search in higher dimensional space"=
 might produce more robust and fit players.  At what computational cost?  I=
f the topological complexity curve for having a "more fit player" is expone=
tial, then doesn't that mean that there is a threshold of diminishing retur=
ns somewhere?  Granted, it may not be.  However, when it is exponential (an=
d my intuition says it is more of the time), we now have an exponent on an =
exponent of complexification which massively enlarges the search space, X^T=
, where T =3D Y^Z and Z is the complexity curve.  If this is true, then we =
are massive amounts of processing power away from achieving result in anyth=
ing but the simplest of domains, like XOR and Tic-Tac-Toe.

Am I missing so=
mething here?  Perhaps I need to do more direct experimentation and examine=
 the results before jumping to this kind of conclusion.  I just get the sen=
se that simple weight mutation achieved quite a bit in Checkers, a domain m=
ore complex than Tic-Tac-Toe.  It would be interesting to see how Checkers =
might do with NEAT and see what kinds of mutation rates might be more/less =
effective and why.


Jim


  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: John Arr=
owwood 
  To: neat@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Friday, June 04, 2004 4:14 PM
 =
 Subject: Re: [neat] Re: Bloat


  >From: Derek James <djames@...>
  =
>
  >On Fri, 04 Jun 2004 00:42:41 +0100, Colin Green <cgreen@...>=
 
  >wrote:
  > > Consider the problem from the other direction then. If al=
l of of these
  > > useless structures aren't participating positively in a=
 search (on the
  > > whole) then every single improvement seen in a popula=
tion must come from
  > > immediately beneficial single mutations.
  >
  >W=
ell, that's not entirely accurate.  In any new individual generated
  >in N=
EAT, there could be a very large number of mutations at once.
  >Many of it=
s connection weights may be mutated at once, along with the
  >addition (or=
 subtraction) of a fairly large number of topological
  >features.

  That =
seems strange to me.  It seems to me like the more appropriate thing to 
  =
do is to limit mutations to one structural change at a time.  You can add 
=
  one connection, OR you can split one connection (or delete one 
  connect=
ion...), but you can't do any more than that for a given mutation of 
  a g=
iven organism.  Then, each and every change has a chance to prove itself 
 =
 before being added upon.

  > > So anyway, what I was proposing was a meth=
od of getting the best of both
  > > worlds. If excess structure is importa=
nt then keep it, but if the search
  > > has stagnated for a period of time=
 then I would say that the excess
  > > structures have now had plenty of t=
ime to prove themselves - and failed.
  > > They have crossed the line from=
 being possible useful structures into
  > > being useless junk (bloat).
  =
>
  >It would be interesting to see if this view could be tested
  >empiric=
ally.  It was my understanding that the philosophy of NEAT was
  >essential=
ly gradualist in its approach to adding structure, and that
  >was part of =
the appeal of it to me.  It sounds as if you and Ken are
  >both now arguin=
g more for the approach of jumping, via allowing chunks
  >of untested morp=
hology to accumulate in the hope that they will
  >eventually spontaneously=
 contribute to increased fitness.

  I don't think that's what Ken was tryi=
ng to say.

  Picture an experiment.  Focus on one species that is fairly w=
ell developed, 
  but stagnant.  During a generation, the top members breed=
 or are mutated.  
  The mutations add structure.  Some are helpful, maybe.=
  Some hinder.  Others 
  are neutral.  Those that are a hindrence get sele=
cted against.  Those that 
  help are selected for.  But in (this) stagnant=
 population, few single 
  mutations are by themselves helpful.  So a lot o=
f the neutral mutations 
  survive to the next generation.  They are now ca=
rrying something extra.  It 
  doesn't help.  It doesn't hinder.  It's just=
 there.

  At the next generation, the same thing happens.  Now, some porti=
on of the 
  population will not have any extra, some will have one extra, =
and others 
  will have two.  And others will be mixtures thereof.  If that=
 isn't enough 
  to cause a fitness jump, then the process happens again.  =
Again, some will 
  have no extra, some one extra, some two, some three, an=
d many will be 
  variants thereof.  The more generations go by, the bigger=
 the spectrum.  
  However, it will most likely be fairly evenly distribute=
d between those 
  without and those with extra neutral structure.

  As th=
at neutral structure is recombined through crossover, some will be a 
  hin=
drence, and will die out.  Others might be helpful, and others neutral, 
  =
same as with mutation.  If no helpful ones are discovered, then neutral wil=
l 
  remain.

  Eventually, some combination may strike on a configuration =
that results in 
  an improvement in fitness.  At that point, evolution wil=
l favor that 
  configuration.  The stagnation will end.  The point is, to =
get there, you 
  had to add structure.  There's no assurance that all the =
'extraneous' 
  structure that accumulated will be useful, however.

  As f=
or the idea of pruning a stagnant species, that's not all that 
  good...wh=
en you start going forward again, you would undo your pruning as 
  you loo=
k for a way to move forward.  You would need to wait until the 
  stagnant =
species has broken out of that stagnation, and THEN prune.  But I 
  think =
your best bet is to wait until you have found an acceptable solution, 
  an=
d then do a phase that supports pruning in order to optimize that 
  soluti=
on.
